Additional detail on PEPFAR financial information and terminology can be found at https://data.pepfar.gov/financial. The PEPFAR IATI activity file and PEPFAR IATI Activity File User's Guide can be found at https://data.pepfar.gov/additionalData
The commodity management system is a weak link in the Ghanaian health sector, resulting in stock-outs or wastage of critical drugs that impedes performance of key programs including malaria, HIV/AIDs, and family planning. Building the capacity and performance of the Ghanaian Ministry of Health is a key priority within the Ghana Global Health Initiative Strategy and also one of the goals of Ghana's Partnership Framework which is to increase anti-retroviral treatment (ART) coverage from 30% to 60%. The USG is a major advocate for procurement and supply chain streamlining. The GOG and other development partners recognize and appreciate the USG role in this effort. There is new interest of the GOG in making major changes in its system to improve performance, so the USG will continue to engage strongly in this effort, including using lessons from the private sector to encourage the implementation of a national plan to reform the structures and modalities of the procurement and supply system.
Through DELIVER, the USG provides long term, in-country technical assistance to the different agencies in supply chain management, with specific components funded by PEPFAR leveraging other investments from population, malaria and nutrition funding streams. The TA is designed to strengthen national capacity in forecasting, managing, monitoring and reporting on use of program commodities. Beyond these key functions, the USG-provided TA also is a trusted GOG partner in advocacy, strategic planning and coordination efforts across the different agencies involved in the system. DELIVER embarks on quarterly commodity stock monitoring to ensure product availability and update supply plans (pipeline databases) for key health commodities to partners. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.6: Adult Care and Support. All facility-based and home/community-based activities for HIV-infected adults and their families aimed at extending and optimizing quality of life for HIV-infected clients and their families throughout the continuum of illness through provision of clinical, psychological, spiritual, social and prevention services. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.11: Treatment/Adult Treatment. Including infrastructure, training clinicians and other providers, exams, clinical monitoring, related laboratory services, and community-adherence activities. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.9: Counseling and Testing. Includes activities in which both HIV counseling and testing are provided for those who seek to know their HIV status (as in traditional VCT) or provider initiated counseling and testing. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.5: Sexual Prevention - Other Sexual Prevention. Other activities (including training) aimed at preventing HIV transmission including purchase and promotion of condoms, STI management (if not in palliative care settings/context), messages/programs to reduce other risks of persons engaged in high-risk behaviors. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.1: Preventing Mother-to-Child Transmission (PMTCT). Activities (including training) aimed at preventing mother-to-child HIV transmission, including ARV prophylaxis for HIV-infected pregnant women and newborns and counseling and support for maternal nutrition. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.13: Health System Strengthening. Include activities that contribute to national, regional or district level systems by supporting finance, leadership and governance (include broad policy reform efforts including stigma, gender, etc.), institutional capacity building, supply chain or procurement systems, Global Fund programs and donor coordination. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.17: Pediatric Care and Support. All health facility-based care for HIV-exposed children and their families aimed at extending and optimizing quality of life for HIV-infected clients and their families throughout the continuum of illness through provision of clinical, psychological, spiritual, social and prevention services. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.18: Treatment/Pediatric Treatment. Including infrastructure, training clinicians and other providers, exams, clinical monitoring, related laboratory services, and community-adherence activities. objectives
